item.title: Police hunt mayor accused of being Chinese spy
item.description: Authorities fail to arrest mayor whose case has gripped a nation embroiled in a sea dispute with China.

item.title: "I'm Supposed To Be Dead": Trump Recalls Rally Attack In Latest Interview
item.description: Former US president Donald Trump on Sunday told the New York Post he was "supposed to be dead" after surviving an assassination attempt which he described as a "very surreal experience."

item.title: Trump Attacker Was Rejected By School Shooting Club Over "Terrible" Shot
item.description: Thomas Matthew Crooks was shot dead by law enforcement when he allegedly attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania on Saturday.

item.title: "Lord Jagannath Returned Favour": ISKCON Official On Trump Rally Shooting
item.description: Radharamn Das, the Vice President and Spokesperson of Kolkata ISKCON has reacted to the attempted assassination of Donald Trump.

item.title: Who Is Doug Mills, Photographer Who Captured Bullet That Hit Trump's Ear
item.description: He was able to capture the exact moment when the bullet whizzed past Trump's head.

item.title: Fate of top Hamas military commander uncertain after Israel's airstrike in Gaza
item.description: Israel's PM Benjamin Netanyahu has also acknowledged that there was "no certainty" that Deif had been killed. The Israeli military said its strike on Saturday aimed at Deif and Salama in "an open area" that was "not a tent complex, but an operational compound."​​

item.title: Trump assassination attempt: BlackRock issues statement, says shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks featured in ad
item.description: Thomas Matthew Crooks, who attempted to assassinate Trump at a Pennsylvania rally, appeared in a 2022 BlackRock ad as a Bethel Park High School student. Crooks, armed with an AR-style rifle, was killed by Secret Service agents. BlackRock removed the ad, condemned the attack, and will release second-quarter results amid scrutiny over gunmaker investments. Footage provided to authorities.

item.title: Musk criticizes NYT for Trump-related opinion page after assassination attempt
Union’s response to allegations ‘falls short’, minister says – as it happened
item.description:
This blog is now closed.

  • Jacinta Allan seeks suspension of CFMEU construction division from Victorian Labor party
  • Get our morning and afternoon news emails, free app or daily news podcast

Treasurer Jim Chalmers has warned about what he calls the “normalisation of extremism” in politics in the wake of the attempted assassination of former United States president Donald Trump at the weekend.

In a round of television and radio interviews this morning to spruik the tax cuts now being delivered in Australians’ tax returns, Chalmers also spoke about the Trump rally in Pennsylvania that injured the former president and left one attendee dead and two others critically injured before the alleged shooter was shot and killed.

We need to be able to disagree in a peaceful way.

We can’t let extremism and polarisation and violence be the norm in our politics. Democracies are supposed to help mend and moderate our differences, not magnify and horrify them. And unfortunately, what we’re seeing with what feels like increasing regularity, is the ugliness and the polarisation and extremism in politics.

There is a role obviously for peaceful protests and looking for consensus in our country doesn’t always mean looking for unanimity – there will always be a range of views. But I think if you look around the world and you look around the democratic world, then you can see that politics is getting uglier, more violent, more polarised in extreme ways, and these are very troubling developments.

We’ve got a big choice to make as democratic societies, we’ve got an opportunity here to step back from the normalisation of that violence, to make sure that we disagree in civil ways and not in violent ways, and that we settle our difference with votes not violence.

Continue reading...

item.title: Israel-Gaza war live: Deadly weekend of strikes draws condemnation with fate of senior Hamas commander unclear
item.description:
Saturday’s attack on Khan Younis that left more than 90 dead draws criticism; Hamas concealing fate of Mohammed Deif says IDF

  • See all our Israel-Gaza war coverage

Hello and welcome to the Guardian’s continuing coverage of Israel’s war on Gaza and the wider crisis in the Middle East.

Israeli bombing across Gaza over the weekend drew strong condemnation, with Egypt’s foreign ministry saying that Saturday’ strike on Khan Younis, which killed 90 people according to the territory’s emergency services, could not be “accepted under any justification whatsoever”.

Continue reading...

item.title: Labour will be ‘more Southgate, less Gove’ in trying to end division, says Nandy
item.description:
Culture secretary, who watched England lose to Spain with PM, says manager assembled ‘incredible’ team that reflects national story

The Labour government will be “more Gareth Southgate, less Michael Gove” than its predecessor in seeking to end culture war divisions and telling an inclusive story about Britain, the culture secretary, Lisa Nandy, has promised.

Speaking from Berlin, where she watched England lose the Euros final to Spain alongside Keir Starmer, Nandy said that whether or not Southgate decided to stay on as the men’s manager, he had made a hugely significant contribution both in terms of football and more widely.

Continue reading...
